key_points: Derek Chavin found guilty on all charges in the death of George Floyd, inciting relief and righteousness in Chicago.
Chicagoans emotionally react, with many hoping the verdict is a step towards police reform.
National Guard deployed and businesses boarded up in anticipation of potential unrest, but Chicago streets remained peaceful.
Activists in Chicago call for more say in policing in their neighborhoods and vow to continue their fight against racism and police brutality.
Illinois Governor Pritzker deployed 125 National Guard members to assist with street closures and ensure safety during protests.
The deployment of the National Guard aimed at supporting peaceful protests while keeping communities safe.
Despite preparations for potential unrest, there was no actionable intelligence suggesting threats to public safety.
Businesses took preventive measures by boarding up, reflecting lingering apprehension from previous protests.
Public and personal reactions to the verdict vary, with many seeing it as a hopeful sign of justice and accountability.
Criticism remains over Mayor Lightfoot's decision to deploy National Guard troops, with Black and Latinx organizers condemning the move.
spokespersons: Andrew Weisberg (Criminal Defense Attorney and Former Prosecutor)
